channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2024 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Hope, despair and CRISPR — the race to save one woman’s life
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01716-y

Researchers in India fought to develop what could have been the first therapy to use gene-editing to halt a rare neurodegenerative disease. The efforts hold lessons for the messy state of modern drug development.
item.dc:title: Hope, despair and CRISPR — the race to save one woman’s life
item.dc:creator: Heidi Ledford

item.title: CRISPR cures and cancer vaccines: researchers can help to shepherd them to market
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01714-0

It’s not just people with ultra-rare disorders who could benefit from hyper-personalized therapies. Scientists and regulators must work together to ensure the benefits are spread.
item.dc:title: CRISPR cures and cancer vaccines: researchers can help to shepherd them to market

item.title: A virtual rodent predicts the structure of neural activity across behaviors
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07633-4

A virtual rodent predicts the structure of neural activity across behaviors
item.dc:title: A virtual rodent predicts the structure of neural activity across behaviors

item.title: Science profits most when people of faith feel equally welcomed
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01745-7

Science profits most when people of faith feel equally welcomed
item.dc:title: Science profits most when people of faith feel equally welcomed
item.dc:creator: Denis R. Alexander
Robert S. White

item.title: Ancient graves reveal taxes’ sharp bite nearly 3,000 years ago
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01700-6

Buried items show that the poor got poorer as the Assyrian empire and its bureaucracy swelled.
item.dc:title: Ancient graves reveal taxes’ sharp bite nearly 3,000 years ago

item.title: Physics is more than a collection of laws — it is a living craft
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01590-8

The Cavendish Laboratory’s director, Brian Pippard, comments on the landscape of physics research in 1974, plus the benefits of applying thermodynamics to physiology, in the weekly dip in Nature’s archive.
item.dc:title: Physics is more than a collection of laws — it is a living craft

item.title: Equality doesn’t equal sustainability — even high-welfare states must do more
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01746-6

Equality doesn’t equal sustainability — even high-welfare states must do more
item.dc:title: Equality doesn’t equal sustainability — even high-welfare states must do more
item.dc:creator: David Pérez-Neira
Sherman Farhad
Luis Buendía

item.title: CRISPR improves a crop that feeds billions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01701-5

The gene-editing system, normally used to disrupt a gene, is applied to improve the function of a gene in rice.
item.dc:title: CRISPR improves a crop that feeds billions

item.title: Science and religion have profound differences — they should be kept apart
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01744-8

Science and religion have profound differences — they should be kept apart
item.dc:title: Science and religion have profound differences — they should be kept apart
item.dc:creator: Rodrigo Hirata Willemart
Antonio Carlos Marques

item.title: Embryo models need consistent ethical oversight
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01728-8

Embryo models need consistent ethical oversight
item.dc:title: Embryo models need consistent ethical oversight
item.dc:creator: Magdalena Zernicka-Goetz
Insoo Hyun

item.title: A win for global action: harm from some ozone-eroding gases starts to fall
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01733-x

Emissions reductions achieved under the landmark Montreal Protocol mean that the ozone hole could close sooner than expected.
item.dc:title: A win for global action: harm from some ozone-eroding gases starts to fall

item.title: How personalized cancer vaccines could keep tumours from coming back
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01717-x

The same mRNA technology that quickly brought the world a vaccine for COVID-19 is now showing promise as a bespoke therapy for cancer.
item.dc:title: How personalized cancer vaccines could keep tumours from coming back
item.dc:creator: Elie Dolgin

item.title: Open access is working — but researchers in lower-income countries enjoy fewer benefits
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01748-4

Deep-seated aspects of local research systems need to be uprooted to ensure that researchers in low-income countries can harness the advantages of open access.
item.dc:title: Open access is working — but researchers in lower-income countries enjoy fewer benefits
item.dc:creator: Holly Else

item.title: Space weather can affect our daily lives — we need a better warning system
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01715-z

Categorizing geomagnetic storms on a scale of one to five leaves no room for once-a-century superstorms.
item.dc:title: Space weather can affect our daily lives — we need a better warning system
item.dc:creator: Sean Elvidge

item.title: How restorative justice could help to heal science communities torn apart by harassment misconduct
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01739-5

Could a programme used by police to tackle repeat offending be used in academia? Some institutions are keen to find out.
item.dc:title: How restorative justice could help to heal science communities torn apart by harassment misconduct
item.dc:creator: Sarah Wild

item.title: AI & robotics briefing: The year machines will run out of data
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01760-8

Large language models could exhaust the supply of publicly available, human-crafted writing in the next two to eight years. Plus, AI model finds huge cache of potential antibiotics hidden in genomes and Microsoft’s algorithm predicts global air pollution in less than a minute.
item.dc:title: AI & robotics briefing: The year machines will run out of data
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: Elite researchers in China say they had ‘no choice’ but to commit misconduct
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01697-y

Anonymous interviewees say they engaged in unethical behaviour to protect their jobs — although others say study presents an overly negative view.
item.dc:title: Elite researchers in China say they had ‘no choice’ but to commit misconduct
item.dc:creator: Smriti Mallapaty

item.title: How a few days in space can disrupt a person’s biology
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01705-1

Trove of health data from space tourists and astronauts reveals the effects of microgravity, radiation and more.
item.dc:title: How a few days in space can disrupt a person’s biology
item.dc:creator: Heidi Ledford

item.title: Author Correction: Loss of CDK4/6 activity in S/G2 phase leads to cell cycle reversal
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07666-9

Author Correction: Loss of CDK4/6 activity in S/G2 phase leads to cell cycle reversal
item.dc:title: Author Correction: Loss of CDK4/6 activity in S/G2 phase leads to cell cycle reversal
item.dc:creator: James A. Cornwell
Adrijana Crncec
Marwa M. Afifi
Kristina Tang
Ruhul Amin
Steven D. Cappell

item.title: I raise delicate butterflies on the mean streets of New York
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01722-0

Robyn Elman works to protect and conserve monarch butterflies before their dangerous migration down the US East Coast to Mexico.
item.dc:title: I raise delicate butterflies on the mean streets of New York
item.dc:creator: Jack Leeming

item.title: Do elephants have names for each other?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-00797-z

Machine learning and careful observation suggest that some of the animals’ calls are specific to individuals, similar to a person’s name.
item.dc:title: Do elephants have names for each other?
item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy

item.title: Most nearby young star clusters formed in three massive complexes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07496-9

Analysis of data from Gaia Data Release 3 and other large spectroscopic surveys shows that nearly 60% of high-quality young clusters within 1 kpc of the Sun originated from just three distinct star-forming complexes.
item.dc:title: Most nearby young star clusters formed in three massive complexes
item.dc:creator: Cameren Swiggum
João Alves
Robert Benjamin
Sebastian Ratzenböck
Núria Miret-Roig
Josefa Großschedl
Stefan Meingast
Alyssa Goodman
Ralf Konietzka
Catherine Zucker
Emily L. Hunt
Sabine Reffert

item.title: What the science of elections can reveal in this super-election year
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01712-2

As billions of people go to the polls in 2024, political scientists have a lot of data to sift through.
item.dc:title: What the science of elections can reveal in this super-election year
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Plackett

item.title: Daily briefing: Good news for Moderna’s two-in-one COVID and flu vaccine
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01752-8

A combined jab against COVID-19 and influenza has produced positive results in a large clinical trial. Plus, magic tricks reveal how animals think and what to do if you’re denied tenure.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Good news for Moderna’s two-in-one COVID and flu vaccine
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Counting the cost of fashion’s carbon footprint
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01743-9

As a child Sonja Salmon loved chemistry and sewing. Now her research explores ways of reducing the textile industry’s environmental impact.
item.dc:title: Counting the cost of fashion’s carbon footprint
item.dc:creator: Dom Byrne

item.title: How we packed off the giant pandas from the Smithsonian’s National Zoo
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01727-9

As the zoo prepares to welcome two giant pandas from China, its director Brandie Smith discusses the departure of their predecessors, Tian Tian, Mei Xiang and a three-year-old cub.
item.dc:title: How we packed off the giant pandas from the Smithsonian’s National Zoo
item.dc:creator: Anne Gulland

item.title: Far-right gains in European elections: what they mean for climate goals
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01742-w

A shift to the political right in Europe could make it harder to bring in more ambitious green policies, but key net-zero commitments should remain.
item.dc:title: Far-right gains in European elections: what they mean for climate goals
item.dc:creator: Carissa Wong

item.title: How to track the economic impact of public investments in AI
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01721-1

National statistics systems should recognize the researchers whose ideas drive artificial-intelligence applications, not just machines and factory outputs.
item.dc:title: How to track the economic impact of public investments in AI
item.dc:creator: Julia Lane
Jason Owen-Smith
Bruce A. Weinberg

item.title: Alzheimer’s drug with modest benefits wins backing of FDA advisers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01726-w

Donanemab slows progression of symptoms, but questions linger about the durability of its effect.
item.dc:title: Alzheimer’s drug with modest benefits wins backing of FDA advisers
item.dc:creator: Sara Reardon

item.title: Two decades of deep ice cores from Antarctica
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01507-5

In June 2004, the results of an ambitious Antarctic ice-drilling project brought insight into hundreds of thousands of years of climatic changes. The extraordinary sample still has much to offer climate research — even as its successor is being drilled.
item.dc:title: Two decades of deep ice cores from Antarctica
item.dc:creator: Kenji Kawamura
Ikumi Oyabu

item.title: Beyond the trans/cis binary: introducing new terms will enrich gender research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01719-9

We need terms such as ‘gender modality’ that are flexible enough to capture the nuances of human experience but pragmatic enough to serve science.
item.dc:title: Beyond the trans/cis binary: introducing new terms will enrich gender research
item.dc:creator: Florence Ashley
Shari Brightly-Brown
G. Nic Rider

item.title: Sparrow massacres and Cuban vaccines: Books in Brief
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01725-x

Andrew Robinson reviews five of the best science picks.
item.dc:title: Sparrow massacres and Cuban vaccines: Books in Brief
item.dc:creator: Andrew Robinson

item.title: World's first wooden satellite could herald era of greener space exploration
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01456-z

Japan’s satellite will test wood’s resilience in space — wooden Moon shelters are also planned.
item.dc:title: World's first wooden satellite could herald era of greener space exploration
item.dc:creator: Tim Hornyak

item.title: How white supremacy became a global health problem
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01718-w

Racism is a systemic issue — one that we have the knowledge and tools to solve. But is there a will?
item.dc:title: How white supremacy became a global health problem
item.dc:creator: Sirry Alang

item.title: FBI asks scientists for trust in taking anti-Asian bias seriously
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01704-2

At a public forum, US investigators seek to repair damage from China Initiative with researchers of Asian descent.
item.dc:title: FBI asks scientists for trust in taking anti-Asian bias seriously
item.dc:creator: Neil Savage

item.title: Daily briefing: How to figure out which climate-change policies really work
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01737-7

An ‘evidence bank’ could synthesize research to show how well different policies — from carbon taxes to the promotion of electric vehicles — work to address climate change. Plus, a satellite made from magnolia wood and whether scientists make good presidents.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: How to figure out which climate-change policies really work
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Publisher Correction: Interim analyses of a first-in-human phase 1/2 mRNA trial for propionic acidaemia

item.title: ‘Rainbow’, ‘like a cricket’: every bird in South Africa now has an isiZulu name
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01678-1

An effort to create names for wild bird species in the Indigenous language hopes to strengthen conservation research.
item.dc:title: ‘Rainbow’, ‘like a cricket’: every bird in South Africa now has an isiZulu name
item.dc:creator: Sarah Wild

item.title: A huge outbreak of butterflies hit three continents — here’s why
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01653-w

Swarms of painted ladies that descended on the Middle East, northern Africa and Europe have been traced to their source.
item.dc:title: A huge outbreak of butterflies hit three continents — here’s why

item.title: Why female students at an inner London school are seeing scientists in a different light
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01689-y

Julie Gould describes what happened after showing 50 images of working scientists to a bunch of 12–13 year-olds.
item.dc:title: Why female students at an inner London school are seeing scientists in a different light
item.dc:creator: Julie Gould

item.title: I was denied tenure — how do I cope?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01694-1

Researchers can work long and hard for a permanent academic position, only for their hopes to be dashed. Nature sought advice from three scientists who have experienced the same disappointment.
item.dc:title: I was denied tenure — how do I cope?
item.dc:creator: Nikki Forrester

item.title: Daily briefing: Evidence grows that cows spread bird flu through their milk
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01709-x

Astonishing amounts of H5N1 virus have been found in the raw milk of cows infected with avian influenza. Plus, Neanderthal fire pits offer a snapshot of ancient life and how a dad’s diet affects his sons’ health.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Evidence grows that cows spread bird flu through their milk
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: What’s the best way to tackle climate change? An ‘evidence bank’ could help scientists find answers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01683-4

Synthesizing research on which policies are most effective is a key priority in climate science, advocates say.
item.dc:title: What’s the best way to tackle climate change? An ‘evidence bank’ could help scientists find answers
item.dc:creator: Helen Pearson

item.title: CERN’s $17-billion supercollider in question as top funder criticizes cost
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01671-8

Germany has raised doubts about the affordability of the Large Hadron Collider’s planned successor.
item.dc:title: CERN’s $17-billion supercollider in question as top funder criticizes cost
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: Do scientists make good presidents? How five national leaders performed
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01693-2

Following Mexico’s election result, Nature reviews the legacy of well-known politicians with backgrounds in science and engineering.
item.dc:title: Do scientists make good presidents? How five national leaders performed
item.dc:creator: Smriti Mallapaty
Jeff Tollefson
Carissa Wong

item.title: Structure and topography of the synaptic V-ATPase–synaptophysin complex
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07610-x

Structure and topography of the synaptic V-ATPase–synaptophysin complex
item.dc:title: Structure and topography of the synaptic V-ATPase–synaptophysin complex
item.dc:creator: Chuchu Wang
Wenhong Jiang

item.title: Author Correction: High-speed and large-scale intrinsically stretchable integrated circuits
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07416-x

Author Correction: High-speed and large-scale intrinsically stretchable integrated circuits
item.dc:title: Author Correction: High-speed and large-scale intrinsically stretchable integrated circuits

item.title: China seeks global impact and recognition
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01595-3

The country’s lead in high-quality research looks set to shape the direction of world science.
item.dc:title: China seeks global impact and recognition
item.dc:creator: Simon Baker

item.title: AI finds huge cache of anti-bacterial peptides hidden in genomic data
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01654-9

Machine-learning technique uncovers nearly 900,000 microbe-fighting peptide sequences in genomes collected from soils and other sources.
item.dc:title: AI finds huge cache of anti-bacterial peptides hidden in genomic data

item.title: These Neanderthal fire pits offer an extraordinarily precise snapshot of ancient life
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/d41586-024-01688-z

Researchers used traces of Earth’s changing magnetic field in sediments to identify the activity of ancient humans.
item.dc:title: These Neanderthal fire pits offer an extraordinarily precise snapshot of ancient life
item.dc:creator: Ewen Callaway

item.title: A virally encoded high-resolution screen of cytomegalovirus dependencies
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07503-z

A genetic screen that expresses single guide RNA libraries targeting host genes in the human cytomegalovirus genome enables identification of host factors and provides insights into their roles during the viral replication cycle.
item.dc:title: A virally encoded high-resolution screen of cytomegalovirus dependencies
item.dc:creator: Yaara Finkel
Aharon Nachshon
Einav Aharon
Tamar Arazi
Elena Simonovsky
Martina Dobešová
Zack Saud
Avi Gluck
Tal Fisher
Richard J. Stanton
Michal Schwartz
Noam Stern-Ginossar

item.title: A disease-associated gene desert directs macrophage inflammation through ETS2
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07501-1

ETS2—which is associated with inflammatory bowel disease, ankylosing spondylitis, primary sclerosing cholangitis and Takayasu’s arteritis—is a central regulator of human inflammatory macrophages.
item.dc:title: A disease-associated gene desert directs macrophage inflammation through ETS2
item.dc:creator: C. T. Stankey

item.title: Profiling phagosome proteins identifies PD-L1 as a fungal-binding receptor
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07499-6

Proximity labelling of phagosomal contents is used to identify proteins that localize to phagosomes in host–microorganism interactions.
item.dc:title: Profiling phagosome proteins identifies PD-L1 as a fungal-binding receptor
item.dc:creator: Kai Li
Avradip Chatterjee
Chen Qian
Katherine Lagree
Yang Wang
Courtney A. Becker
Michael R. Freeman
Ramachandran Murali
Wei Yang
David M. Underhill

item.title: MYCT1 controls environmental sensing in human haematopoietic stem cells
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07478-x

MYCT1 is identified as a crucial regulator of cellular properties essential for the stemness of human haematopoietic stem cells, a finding that may help improve successful in vitro expansion of these cells for therapeutics.
item.dc:title: MYCT1 controls environmental sensing in human haematopoietic stem cells
item.dc:creator: Júlia Aguadé-Gorgorió
Yasaman Jami-Alahmadi
Vincenzo Calvanese
Maya Kardouh

item.title: Observation of 2D-magnesium-intercalated gallium nitride superlattices
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07513-x

The spontaneous formation of magnesium-intercalated gallium nitride superlattices by the interstitial intercalation of two-dimensional magnesium results in considerable compressive strain perpendicular to the layers, leading to enhanced hole transport.
item.dc:title: Observation of 2D-magnesium-intercalated gallium nitride superlattices
item.dc:creator: Jia Wang
Wentao Cai
Weifang Lu
Shun Lu
Emi Kano
Verdad C. Agulto

Hirotaka Watanabe
Nobuyuki Ikarashi
Toshiyuki Iwamoto
Makoto Nakajima
Yoshio Honda
Hiroshi Amano

item.title: Fault-network geometry influences earthquake frictional behaviour
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07518-6

Analysis of some of the main fault zones in California shows that the presence of complex earthquake fault-network geometries results in geometric locking that promotes stick-slip behaviour, whereas simpler geometries lead to smooth fault creep.
item.dc:title: Fault-network geometry influences earthquake frictional behaviour
item.dc:creator: Jaeseok Lee
Victor C. Tsai
Greg Hirth
Avigyan Chatterjee
Daniel T. Trugman

item.title: Injectable ultrasonic sensor for wireless monitoring of intracranial signals
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07334-y

A bioresorbable, wireless hydrogel (metagel) sensor, encompassing both biodegradable and stimulus-responsive hydrogels for ultrasonic monitoring of intracranial signals, was implanted into intracranial space with a puncture needle and deformed in response to physiological environmental changes.
item.dc:title: Injectable ultrasonic sensor for wireless monitoring of intracranial signals
item.dc:creator: Hanchuan Tang
Yueying Yang
Zhen Liu
Wenlong Li

item.title: A late-Ediacaran crown-group sponge animal
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07520-y

Cross-hatch impressions from Ediacaran rocks in China are interpreted as having been left by a crown-group sponge fossil, Helicolocellus cantori gen. et sp. nov., characterized by an organic latticework skeleton.
item.dc:title: A late-Ediacaran crown-group sponge animal
item.dc:creator: Xiaopeng Wang
Alexander G. Liu
Zhe Chen
Chengxi Wu
Yarong Liu
Bin Wan
Ke Pang
Chuanming Zhou
Xunlai Yuan
Shuhai Xiao

item.title: Myelin plasticity in the ventral tegmental area is required for opioid reward
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07525-7

Oligodendrogenesis is shown to be involved in reward learning, with dopaminergic neuronal activity-regulated myelin plasticity being an important reward circuit modification.
item.dc:title: Myelin plasticity in the ventral tegmental area is required for opioid reward
item.dc:creator: Belgin Yalçın
Matthew B. Pomrenze
Karen Malacon
Richard Drexler
Abigail E. Rogers
Kiarash Shamardani
Isabelle J. Chau
Kathryn R. Taylor
Lijun Ni
Daniel Contreras-Esquivel
Robert C. Malenka
Michelle Monje

item.title: Misunderstanding the harms of online misinformation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07417-w

This Perspective identifies common misperceptions regarding the harms of online misinformation, finding that exposure to false and inflammatory content is rare and concentrated among a small minority of people who already have extreme views.
item.dc:title: Misunderstanding the harms of online misinformation
item.dc:creator: Ceren Budak
Brendan Nyhan
David M. Rothschild
Emily Thorson
Duncan J. Watts

item.title: Early stages of covalent organic framework formation imaged in operando
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07483-0

The operando imaging of the early formation stages of covalent organic frameworks with the optical technique interferometric scattering microscopy leads to mechanistic insights, enabling the rational development of a synthesis protocol at room temperature instead of elevated temperatures.
item.dc:title: Early stages of covalent organic framework formation imaged in operando
item.dc:creator: Christoph G. Gruber
Laura Frey
Roman Guntermann
Dana D. Medina
Emiliano Cortés

item.title: Nuclear position and local acetyl-CoA production regulate chromatin state
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07471-4

Analyses of histone acetylation in Drosophila wing imaginal discs reveal distinct patterns of acetylation and cellular metabolism that affect gene expression and cell specification.
item.dc:title: Nuclear position and local acetyl-CoA production regulate chromatin state
item.dc:creator: Philipp Willnow
Aurelio A. Teleman

item.title: The time between Palaeolithic hearths
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07467-0

High-resolution time differences between six Middle Palaeolithic hearths from El Salt Unit x (Spain) obtained through archaeomagnetic and archaeostratigraphic analyses show sometimes decade-long intervals between hearths.
item.dc:title: The time between Palaeolithic hearths
item.dc:creator: Ángela Herrejón-Lagunilla
Juan José Villalaín
Francisco Javier Pavón-Carrasco
Mario Serrano Sánchez-Bravo
Santiago Sossa-Ríos
Alejandro Mayor
Bertila Galván
Cristo M. Hernández
Carolina Mallol
Ángel Carrancho

item.title: Senescent glia link mitochondrial dysfunction and lipid accumulation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07516-8

The authors identify naturally occurring senescent glia in aged Drosophila brains and decipher their origin and influence, determining that they can appear in response to neuronal mitochondrial dysfunction and that they promote lipid accumulation, indicating that these cells link key ageing phenomena.
item.dc:title: Senescent glia link mitochondrial dysfunction and lipid accumulation
item.dc:creator: China N. Byrns
Alexandra E. Perlegos
Karl N. Miller
Zhecheng Jin
Faith R. Carranza

Nancy M. Bonini

item.title: Descending networks transform command signals into population motor control
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07523-9

Command-like descending neurons in Drosophila melanogaster recruit additional descending neuronal networks to co-ordinate behaviours that require multiple motor subroutines controlling numerous body parts.
item.dc:title: Descending networks transform command signals into population motor control
item.dc:creator: Jonas Braun
Femke Hurtak
Sibo Wang-Chen
Pavan Ramdya

item.title: Large-area, self-healing block copolymer membranes for energy conversion
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07481-2

We introduce a self-assembly strategy that uses the interface of an aqueous two-phase system to template and stabilize molecularly thin biomimetic block copolymer bilayers of scalable area that can exceed 10 cm2 without defects.
item.dc:title: Large-area, self-healing block copolymer membranes for energy conversion
item.dc:creator: Christian C. M. Sproncken

item.title: Scaling neural machine translation to 200 languages
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2024; doi:10.1038/s41586-024-07335-x

Scaling neural machine translation to 200 languages is achieved by No Language Left Behind, a single massively multilingual model that leverages transfer learning across languages.
item.dc:title: Scaling neural machine translation to 200 languages
